intro: Myrciaria leucophloea var. laxa, commonly known as the white-flowered myrcia, is a shrub native to the Atlantic Forest of Brazil. It is characterized by its white, fragrant flowers that bloom in clusters, often attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The plant has glossy, elliptical leaves that are typically arranged alternately along the stems. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in understory layers of dense tropical forests. The fruit, which is a small, yellowish drupe, is edible and has a sweet, acidic flavor.
